instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight
threads.message:
Hi. i have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight. i replaced lcd connector and also <CHIP>U6701</CHIP> and still no backlight .
F9700- 12v pin 1 and pin 2
<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>- pin 1 0.430v and pin 2 0.122v
<TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>- pin 2 3.34v pin 5 0.036v
<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>- pin 1,2,5,6 0.0053v

any help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight
threads.message: Screen isn't being detected. Is it plugged in when you are measuring?

threads.message: Is there an image on the LCD? Check with flashlight.

threads.message: screen is connected and is apple logo coming up. of course i checked with flash light

threads.message: I have no idea, you are just "doing" things and not using brains. Reballing the GPU is NEVER an option, always use new. But this was never a GPU issue to start with, as I said use brains.

threads.message: i know m8. i never started from gpu. i done all testing tricks and gpu was last thing i done. am waiting for new chipset coming from china so i dint had this model left so has to try reballed. i changed 3 screens, replaced two connectors, two ic and all that but still not back light so i done gpu last. but is still this same problem. i know you are much more better with fixing boards. am just start learning this 1 year ago and of course will; do lots of mistakes like everybody do  . that how is it work. not sure what to do now to get this back light back again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight
threads.message: really need to fix this board today. can you help duke?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight
threads.message:
Replacing <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> makes no sense here. <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> takes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>'s main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is not opening, then you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. We can't blame <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> for not working and replace it when it isn't receiving the power required to turn on. This is like changing a lightbulb while the switch is set to off. Turn the switch on, [I]then[/I] see if the lightbulb works.

So why isnt <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> sending power to the backlight circuit? <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate ate identical.

How would we lover the voltage on <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>'s gate at pin 3 so that it will turn on? Look at <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR>. If we take <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> and put it to ground right after <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> now we have a voltage divider. Voltage dividers lower voltage! A hah. So why isn't it lowering? <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> needs a path to ground in order for <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> to [I]be [/I]a voltage divider. What gives <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> a path to ground? <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> is the opposite of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>. It's an N channel MOSFET. It will turn "on" when the power on the gate is equal to or higher than the source. <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>, once it is 3.3v, ,will be higher than the 0v(ground) on pin 1, which will open the first transistor. <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, when 3.3v, will be higher than the 0v on the source(ground pin 4) and open the second transistor. This will give <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> a path to ground, making <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> a voltage divider, which will lower the voltage on pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> to around 5v, which will allow it to open.

Before this occurs, there is no point in troubleshooting anything after <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>. It just won't work.

<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing in your case. This comes from <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. What does <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> do? Look at the beginning of the schematic. This is responsible for taking the video signal from the integrated intel graphics & the AMD GPU and sending it off to either displayport external screen or internal LCD. <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is going to be responsible for brightness control, as well as turning the screen on. So let's go over the cases under which <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> might not send out <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>.

Anytime you see an image and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high - meaning, the machine does not think the lid is closed, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> should be high as well. Is <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> a solid 3.4v? If it is, and you are doing something with the machine like clicking the mouse or touching the keyboard, then <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> should be present. If not, try resetting PRAM. This always fixes it for duke because he's luckier than I am - I always wind up having a fucked up mux. :( If it isn't a low <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> value, or a PRAM reset, then <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is the next culprit.

If you want to "cheat" and see if the rest of the backlight circuit works, you can wire pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> and pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>. If you get a backlight then it is most likely a <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> issue. This is obviously a cancerous thing to do because you will have full brightness all the time, but allows you to see that the rest of everything in front of <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is working.

Most likely replacing a <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, which of course comes with firmware, which means salvaging one from a donor board and reballing it, which is a horrorshow. and then selling to the customer that you're not refunding them for the board repair when the GPU dies a month later. I don't envy you right now. ;)

As duke said, there has to be a logical reason to everything. If you don't get it, post, but replacing chips that aren't even getting power and hoping it turns on is the opposite of the logical reasoning required to fix this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no backlight
threads.message:
great lesson m8. now i understand how is it work now. i see your video when you say about two signals enable on <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> must be present and i check for it and find out that <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is missing  now i wired pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> and pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and i have back light so now i know <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is faulty.  i dont have stencil  for this ic so i will just leave it like it is us long is working. Also i will replace gpu for customer any way when i get delivery from china after chines new year with new machine zm-<RESISTOR>R6200C</RESISTOR>. Thanks again for all this info. that was the best way to explain how this all work.   Problem fixed

can you pls correct my title ?:) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  lol
